Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small : Collaborative Research: Towards a Green Cellular Network through User and Application Aware Dynamic Cell Reconfiguration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores the design of green cellular network architectures and algorithms to reduce energy consumption. A major consumer of energy in cellular networks is the operation of the base stations. Most base stations are deployed and operated continuously based on peak traffic estimates. Intuitively, it saves energy to judiciously "scale back" un-utilized and under-utilized base stations during off-peak times. The remaining base stations must adapt accordingly so that the required coverage is maintained.

The PIs propose a dynamically adaptive cellular network where the cell size and capacity of the base stations are dynamically reconfigured based on the current user locations and Quality of Service (QoS) demands of the applications. Modeling of the network power consumption based on the network topography, followed by optimization of the topography is the key to this problem. The project will involve student participation at all stages through suitably designed projects. The results of the research will be disseminated through professional journals and conference proceedings and also through industry forums and workshops. Furthermore, the project addresses one of the most pressing issues of today, namely, reducing the carbon footprint of the cellular network. Radical new designs for the network have the potential to spur economic development, create jobs and forge stronger communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless networks offering high data rates and enhanced coverage, and mobile devices with increasing screen resolutions and processing capable of high quality video and web browsing, are key drivers fueling an explosive growth in mobile multimedia traffic. Since multimedia is both data rate intensive, and compute intensive, this trend is leading to steep increase in the power consumption of cellular networks, particularly of base stations and mobile devices. In this project, we explored the design of "green" cellular networks, proposing novel real-time rate adaptation, and base station and mobile device reconfiguration techniques, to reduce power consumption of both mobile devices and base stations.

We start with two key observations: more than two-thirds of the total mobile data traffic by 2015 is expected to be video, and while the increased video usage will significantly increase battery consumption of mobile devices, lack of comparable improvements in mobile battery technologies will lead to frustratingly lower battery lifetimes. Hence, we have developed battery aware video delivery techniques that utilize device buffer and battery characteristics to vary video bit rate and video download rate, and reconfigure the radio frequency (RF) and baseband components of the base station and mobile device, in a way that reduces the battery load imposed by the RF and baseband processing on the mobile device. Also, if buffer level permits, video download and hence the related processing on the mobile device is stopped at certain times, which significantly lowers the current drawn from the battery (whose effect on battery is equivalent to that of idling), and enables charge recovery thereby increasing battery lifetime. The proposed battery aware video delivery techniques ensure that the minimum desired level of user experience is maintained while maximizing battery lifetime during mobile video download. Experiments conducted under various network conditions and for various types of video download profiles have shown that more than 50% increase in mobile battery lifetime is possible with no degradation in user experience when using the proposed technique compared to currently used HTTP progressive video download, and more than 40% increase in mobile battery lifetime is possible with marginal degradation in user experience when our battery aware adaptive bit rate (ABR) streaming technique is used compared to the current ABR techniques like DASH.

To reduce cellular network power consumption due to base stations (which consume 60-80% of cellular network power) while satisfying quality of service (QoS) requirements of users, we have developed new dynamic cell reconfiguration (DCR) techniques that adapt cell size and capacity through active base station selection, user association and base station transmit power adaptation. While active base station selection involves deciding which base stations remain on in order to satisfy the QoS of all users in the network and which base stations can be switched off in order to minimize network power consumption, user association focuses on load balancing and decides which base station the user should be assigned to in order to optimize the utilization of base stations. Adapting transmit power aims at determining the optimal transmit power of active base stations required to satisfy the QoS requirement of users and further minimize the cellular network power consumption.
